items.title: why does not keyring  install "secretstorage" on mac?
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
I did a fresh install of `keyring` with version `21.3.0` and found `secretstorage` was not installed (not in `Pipfile.lock`). Then I took a look at : https://github.com/jaraco/keyring/blob/master/setup.cfg#L24-L28
```
install_requires =
	pywin32-ctypes!=0.1.0,!=0.1.1; sys_platform=="win32"
	SecretStorage>=3; sys_platform=="linux"
	jeepney>=0.4.2; sys_platform=="linux"
	importlib_metadata; python_version < "3.8"
```
which clearly states it will install `SecretStorage` on linux. My question is why it does not need to install on mac? 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1: install keyring
>pip install keyring

2: check `Pipfile.lock`


**Expected behavior**
`secretstorage` should be installed on mac as well (appear in `Pipfile.lock`)

**Environment**
macos
- OS: [e.g. macOS]


**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

items.title: SecretService get_credential doesn't return None for missing entry
items.body:
When calling `keyring.get_credential` using [the SecretService backend](https://github.com/jaraco/keyring/blob/fb74a37d54657b279c76360cf82b850ba33d1654/keyring/backends/SecretService.py#L105-L124), if a username is provided but the corresponding entry doesn't exist in the keyring, a Credential object with the provided username (and no password) is returned, instead of None. This is in contrast to what happens in [the default implementation](https://github.com/jaraco/keyring/blob/fb74a37d54657b279c76360cf82b850ba33d1654/keyring/backend.py#L125-L138), where None is returns if  the entry is not found.

This causes pypa/pip#8634

### Reproduction
```python
>>> import keyring
>>> c = keyring.get_credential("spam", "eggs")
```

#### Expected
```python
>>> print(c)
None
```

#### Actual
```python
>>> print(c)
<keyring.credentials.SimpleCredential object at 0x...>
>>> print(c.username, c.password)
eggs None
```

#### Environment
* OS: Ubuntu 20.04.1
* keyring: 21.2.1 (first seen in 19.2)
  * keyring.backends.chainer.ChainerBackend (priority: -1)
  * keyring.backends.SecretService.Keyring (priority: 5)
  * keyring.backends.fail.Keyring (priority: 0)

items.title: Pyinstaller still preventing keyring functionality as exe with Windows 10
Error accessing Windows Credential Manager in script compiled to exe by PyInstaller
items.body:
I created a simple demo script, which just prints out the username and password of a credential.  This works fine when run via python, but errors out when run after being compiled with PyInstaller.

Here's my test script, print_credential.py
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python

import sys
import keyring


def printCred(credName):
    #keyring.set_keyring(keyring.backends.Windows.WinVaultKeyring())
    cred = keyring.get_credential(credName, "")
    print(f"Username: {cred.username}")
    print(f"Password: {cred.password}")


if __name__ == '__main__':
    printCred(sys.argv[1])
```

When a test run:
```
~\Projects\python_class> py.exe .\print_credential.py "MyNewTestSystem"
Username: MyTestUser
Password: MyTestPassword
```

Compiled with PyInstaller:
```
~\Projects\python_class> pyinstaller --onefile print_credential.py
```
This creates the exe without error.

And run:
```
~\Projects\python_class> .\dist\print_credential.exe "MyNewTestSystem"
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "print_credential.py", line 15, in <module>
    printCred(sys.argv[1])
  File "print_credential.py", line 9, in printCred
    cred = keyring.get_credential(credName, "")
  File "site-packages\keyring\core.py", line 74, in get_credential
  File "site-packages\keyring\backend.py", line 135, in get_credential
  File "site-packages\keyring\backends\fail.py", line 25, in get_password
keyring.errors.NoKeyringError: No recommended backend was available. Install a recommended 3rd party backend package; or
, install the keyrings.alt package if you want to use the non-recommended backends. See https://pypi.org/project/keyring
 for details.
[32620] Failed to execute script print_credential
```

I've tried running with the --hidden-import option, with win32ctypes, pywintypes, and win32cred, but nothing I tried got it working.  I tried forcefully setting the backend to windows, as can be seen in the commented out line in the script, but that didn't change anything.  Are there other includes or other options needed to make this work?

Edit: versions
```
~\Projects\python_class> python --version
Python 3.6.8

~\Projects\python_class> pip show keyring pyinstaller
Name: keyring
Version: 21.2.1
---
Name: PyInstaller
Version: 3.6
```

items.title: Module cannot be installed under Macos Catalina?
items.body: Hi. I have attempted to install keyring with `pip3 install keyring` but any python program which attempts to import it cannot find the module and the command `keyring` is not found in command line. I also attempted to install with `pip install keyring`. Other modules installed with pip work fine. Thanks

items.title: keyring logging at info level as side effect of being imported
items.body:
This line:

https://github.com/jaraco/keyring/blob/master/keyring/backend.py#L187

generates INFO logs on import. I believe this type of information, given that it's generated as a side effect of import, should be DEBUG to avoid generating output on something as innocuous as import.

If the information must be logged as INFO, I believe this behavior should be deferred until needed, rather.

Imports are hard to order and in any complex environment as effectively non-deterministic. This makes the INFO log output nondeterministic, which makes testing very difficult. Given the core role of keyring in the Python ecosystem, logged output at the INFO level can pop up in surprising ways.

items.title: Allow fetching a username/password pair without specifying the user
items.body:
**Use Case:** For historical reasons, our company is currently using two AD instances (work is ongoing to merge) and users have different user-names on both. Some services use one, some the other. So the user-name is not known in advance. I can only use the local user-name for one of those ADs.

The credential manager already contains credentials with the appropriate username/password pairs but I am unable to fetch them using `keyring` as I don't know the username in advance.

* In a `.netrc` file, it is possible to retrieve a username/password pair with only knowing the service name.
* In the Windows Credential Manager a "Generic Credential" also stores only one username per service, so the service-name is sufficient to retrieve the credentials (see https://gist.github.com/exhuma/a310f927d878b3e5646dc67dfa509b42)

I could imagine one of the following interfaces on `keyring`:

    # Make the username optional. If there exist implementations with multiple
    # credentials per service, this may become non-deterministic (depending on back-end).
    def get_credential(service: str, username: str = '') -> Optional[SimpleCredential]: ...

or a new function `get_credentials`:

    # A new function to list credentials. This should be deterministic no matter
    # which back-end is used, and does not change any existing implementation:
    def get_credentials(service: str) -> Set[SimpleCredential]: ...

items.title: Mysterious problems since keyring 16.0.1 (somehow caused by traceback kept in global variable)
items.body:
Long story:
   https://bz.mercurial-scm.org/show_bug.cgi?id=6043
(mostly read from comment 14)

Short story: change introduced in 
https://github.com/jaraco/keyring/commit/c778a14ecccccb2407edc9347f0cdf40b97b3413
caused problems when keyring is imported inside Mercurial (with it's demandimport machinery). What is more funny, we see and test those problems on Linux and Mac.

I have no idea what's exactly going on and which part of the code is really guilty, but the whole problem narrows down to  traceback object being kept by keyring/backends/Windows.py in global variable (missing_deps) - most likely traceback keeps frames alive, frames keeps some variables alive etc.

Considering missing_deps is used there only as a boolean (to test whether there were any problems), please consider keeping such a flag instead. Fixes like:
```
with ExceptionRaisedContext() as missing_deps:
     #…

if missing_deps:
    missing_deps = True
```
or
```
with ExceptionRaisedContext() as missing_deps:
     #…

if missing_deps:
    missing_deps.traceback = None
```
resolve the issue.

(maybe it would be even better to reconsider keeping .traceback inside keyring.errors.ExceptionInfo, this attribute is not used for anything)

PS As I checked, this is the only place in keyring code where ExceptionInfo object is kept for a long time, other places using ExceptionRaisedContext use returned object temporarily.

items.title: default backend is not deterministic
items.body:
When no backends are available, keyring.backends.chainer.ChainerBackend & keyring.backends.fail.Keyring end up having the same priority of 0
Because keyring.backend.get_all_keyring() is not deterministic, keyring.init_backend() isn't either as shown below.
As a result, behaviour is unpredictable, including raising a vague RuntimeError() exception:

```
$ repeat 10 python3 -c 'import keyring
print(keyring.backend.get_all_keyring()) 
try:                                                 
  print(keyring.get_password("not", "deterministic"))
except Exception as e:
  print(str(e))'
[<keyring.backends.chainer.ChainerBackend object at 0x7f914dcd85c0>, <keyring.backends.fail.Keyring object at 0x7f914ce7ad30>]
None
[<keyring.backends.fail.Keyring object at 0x7f8ed963d5f8>, <keyring.backends.chainer.ChainerBackend object at 0x7f8ed87dfc88>]
No recommended backend was available. Install the keyrings.alt package if you want to use the non-recommended backends. See README.rst for details.
[....]
```

items.title: Keyring tells user to use non-recommended backends
items.body:
In the case where no backend can be found, keyring errors with `RuntimeError: No recommended backend was available.  Install the keyrings.alt package if you want to use the non-recommended backends.`

Not only are `keyrings.alt` backends not recommended, they "may have security risks or other implications".

This, in spite of the fact that there are many valid 3rd party backends available.  

I appreciate the fact that this is documented in the README, but the error message should also state this fact or list a url where this fact can be found.

items.title: Nuclear codes stored using insecure "keyring" by default
items.body:
Keyring stores secrets in a completely non-secure way by default, with no warning nor notification.

Steps to reproduce:
1) Install Alpine Linux.  (It's easiest to do this by installing Docker  https://www.docker.com/products/docker-desktop and then running `docker run -it alpine:3.8`)
2) `apk add --update --no-cache musl-dev=1.1.19-r10 python2-dev=2.7.15-r1 py2-pip=10.0.1-r0 gcc=6.4.0-r9 libffi-dev=3.2.1-r4 openssl-dev=1.0.2q-r0 libxml2-dev=2.9.8-r1 libxslt-dev=1.1.32-r0`
3) `pip install --upgrade pip==18.1`
4) `pip install keyring==17.1.1 keyrings.alt==3.1.1`
5) `keyring set nuke_codes dTrump`
6) `python -c "import keyring; print(keyring.get_keyring())"`

Expected result:
Some kind of secure keyring is used. Or, at the very least, `keyring.backends.fail.Keyring (priority: 0)` is used.

Actual result:
`keyrings.alt.file.PlaintextKeyring (priority: 0.5)`

I never explicitly chose the Plaintext keyring, nor was there any warning nor notification that an insecure keyring was being used.  It was only on a whim that I decided to check which keyring was being used, and boy was I ever glad I did.  

Honestly, the Plaintext keyring should have a negative priority by default.  

You don't want to contribute to the apocalypse, do you?

items.title: keyring 16.0.0 breaks keyrings.alt.file.PlaintextKeyring
items.body:
Steps to reproduce:

Start a fresh Python 3 environment on Ubuntu Bionic. For example:

```
lxc launch ubuntu:bionic keyring
lxc exec keyring -- login -f ubuntu
sudo apt update && sudo apt -y install virtualenv
virtualenv --python=python3 keyring
. keyring/bin/activate
```
Install `keyring` 16.0.0 and `keyrings.alt`:

```
pip3 install keyring==16.0.0 keyrings.alt
```
(this uses `keyrings.alt` 3.1 which is currently the latest in PyPI)

Run the following:

```
python3 -c 'import keyring; print(keyring.get_keyring())'
```

Expected result:

```
keyrings.alt.file.PlaintextKeyring (priority: 0.5)
```

Actual result:

```
keyring.backends.fail.Keyring (priority: 0)
```

Downgrading `keyring` to 15.2.0 works around the problem:

```
$ pip3 install keyring==15.2.0
[...]
$ python3 -c 'import keyring; print(keyring.get_keyring())'
keyrings.alt.file.PlaintextKeyring (priority: 0.5)
```

items.title: Mutable return value
items.body:
It would be cool if, optionally, the return value of a keyring function was a mutable bytestring, allowing the caller to zero it out after use.

Python is a very bad language for crypto in general because of the pervasive use of immutable types, but this lib could at least *try* to give the user an opportunity to clean up.

items.title: Obscure error when credential is longer than allowed
items.body: Using Windows backend, when supplying a password of a sufficient length, the following error is observed: `win32cred.CredWrite(credential, 0) -> (1783, 'CredWrite', 'The stub received bad data')'.`

items.title: Allow all backends to participate
items.body:
Currently, only the highest priority backend (for the special definition of "priority") is used for getting and setting credentials.

I propose the default behavior (that is, before `set_keyring` is called) to allow all discovered backends to participate. My proposed semantics:

## init_backend
Instead of using `max` to select the best keyring in the unconfigured case, use a new backend that includes all those found/filtered by the call (`keyrings` local variable).

## get_password and get_credential
When getting a password, forward the call to each backend in order and return the first non-None result.

## set_password and delete_password
When setting a password, forward the call to each backend in order and return after the first that _does not_ raise `NotImplementedError`.

items.title: Add `get_username_and_password` API
items.body:
There are some scenarios where it is possible (and preferred) to retrieve the username for a service from just the system, but currently keyring has no ability to return a username that has not been provided by the caller.

I propose to add a new API matching `get_password`'s signature, but named `get_username_and_password` ad returning `(username, password)`, where `username` _might_ match the provided username. The ABC can include a default implementation of this that uses `get_password` and returns the provided username.

items.title: SecretStorage dependency no longer requires python-dbus
items.body: That means one should be able to install `keyring` with `pip` without any issues. Time to update that in the documentation, specially `README.md`?

items.title: Add field to set label
items.body:
Currently, all entries are saved with `Password for '%s' on '%s'` label.

It would be nice to be able to set a custom description.

[Source](https://github.com/jaraco/keyring/blob/master/keyring/backends/SecretService.py#L86)

items.title: appid field in SecretService keyring backend causes duplication issues.
items.body:
When you save a password using this library, the password contains an 'application' field containing the app that set the password (python, or the name of the python script from which the function is called). Two otherwise identical passwords can be stored if they are different only by that field.

This can cause different scripts to create duplicates of the same password with no way of selecting which of the two passwords they want to retrieve with get_password. Get_password doesn't even use the 'application' field but will return the most recent password meeting the service/username criteria. delete_password() will delete the first one too.

items.title: request to improve man page with practical examples
items.body:
I'm a bit confused as what are the SERVICE and USERNAME parameter of keyring(1) utility. I'm using gnome-keyring so there are a few possibilities:

1. service is gnome-keyring

2. typically, there are two keyrings, `login` which is unlocked by login, and `user`. `SERVICE` could mean the name of the keyring.

The first is semantically correct but then there seem to be missing a parameter for keyring name before `USERNAME`.

The second is semantically incorrect but makes more sense if you consider the hierarchy: `USERNAME` to be an object under `SERVICES` and items in gnome-keyring is under keyrings.

In practice, setting username under an imagined service called `test` causes an entry to be created in the 'login' keyring, which is very confusing (because nowhere in the commandline mentions the 'login' keyring):

    $ keyring set test username --keyring-backend=keyring.backends.SecretService.Keyring

Since keyring(1) is a userland utility it should make sense for the users.

After a look at the way keyring works I figured out the right explanation:

       keyring provides a way to store, lookup and delete passwords in various
       backends supported by Python-Keyring.

       Usage example:

       # create an entry in the current keyring
       $ keyring set system joe
       Password for 'joe' in 'system':
       # the newly created item looks like this:
       # {"service": "system", "username": 'joe', "password": "[the new password]"}

items.title: Provide a nicer way to disable keyring
items.body:
Historically, the recommended way to disable keyring was to uninstall it... but as revealed in pypa/twine#338, it's not always possible for a user who has keyring installed by a system package manager to uninstall a package without also uninstalling or invalidating other packages.

So let's provide a simple mechanism that disables keyring. Here's what I have in mind:

- [x] Provide a Null Keyring backend that returns None for all `get` operations.
- [x] Provide a command-line that configures the user's environment for this Null keyring. Something like `keyring --disable`.
- [x] ~~For one-off invocations, also honor an environment variable like DISABLE_PYTHON_KEYRING that if present will give priority to the Null keyring.~~
- [x] For one-off invocations, honor an environment variable PYTHON_KEYRING_BACKEND to select a particular keyring such as the Null keyring.

items.title: LICENSE missing in PyPI tarball
items.body: Installation fails because `LICENSE` is referenced in `setup.cfg`.

items.title: How can we improve the experience on Linux?
items.body:
Presently there are a few large user experience issues with Keyring on Linux:

1. The dependency on python-dbus is tricky. It seems like moving to Jeepney is already being considered: https://github.com/jaraco/keyring/issues/301
2. Working with headless installations is [difficult](https://github.com/jaraco/keyring#using-keyring-on-headless-linux-systems). Would it be possible for us to consider starting the dbus daemon automatically if needed?

items.title: Keyring should load all backends through entry points
items.body:
Currently, keyring loads backends through two mechanisms. First, it loads the four built-in backends explicitly. Then, it loads backends declared as entry points. A simpler, more congruent approach would be for keyring to declare its own backends as entry points and load all backends as entry points.

The main downside to this approach is keyring would no longer work on platforms that don't support entry points... so for a narrow population, that would break compatibility. I'm not sure what that population is or if it exists at all.

Perhaps it would be possible to detect that condition and raise a warning (but retain compatibility) to assess the impact.

items.title: D-Bus instructions need more detail in README
items.body:
I'm having trouble using keyring on a headless Linux system. The instructions in the _Using Keyring on headless Linux systems_ section aren't detailed enough for me. I consider myself a novice-to-intermediate Linux user and I can get most things running with the help of a search engine and a bit of trial and error, but I'm stuck here and I suspect many others will be too.

Here are the parts that are unclear to me:

> When that command is started, enter your password into stdin and press Ctrl+D (end of data). After that the daemon will fork into background (use --foreground option to prevent that).

OK, so I got this far. But why mention the `--foreground` option? When would I use that?

> Now you can use the SecretService backend of Keyring. Remember to run your application in the same D-Bus session as the daemon.

How do I run another application in the same D-Bus session? Can we add an example here?

The main problem is that I'm not familiar with D-Bus. I think that might be the case for many novice users. I'm not suggesting that a in-depth description of D-Bus be included in the README, but perhaps a link to further information on D-Bus could be provided.

Note: While this is admittedly a request for help disguised as an issue, I will happily submit a PR for the README if someone can point me in the right direction.

items.title: Moving forward with SecretStorage and D-Bus bindings
items.body:
Hi @jaraco,

One of the major issues with Keyring on Linux is the [dbus-python](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/dbus-python) dependency, which has the following problems:

- It is difficult to install from PyPI: there are no wheels, it needs the D-Bus headers installed locally and compiles itself during install.
- It is not actively developed, and the author [recommends](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/dbus-python#problems-and-alternatives) switching to another library.

Some time ago I created a port of SecretStorage to [Jeepney](https://gitlab.com/takluyver/jeepney), a modern pure-Python library by @takluyver. Please see mitya57/secretstorage#10 and the [wip/jeepney](https://github.com/mitya57/secretstorage/tree/wip/jeepney) branch. I want it to eventually become the new release of SecretStorage.

But Jeepney only supports Python 3.5+, while Keyring aims to support Python 2. So I wonder how we should resolve this issue. I see the following possibilities:

1. Release the branch as a separate project, like `secretstorage-ng`. Tweak `setup.py` to select `secretstorage-ng` for newer Pythons and `secretstorage` for older Pythons. The module name will not change, so `secretstorage` and `secretstorage-ng` will conflict with each other.
2. Release the branch as `secretstorage 3.0a1`. PyPI will not pull it automatically, but `setup.py` can select `secretstorage>=3.0a1` for newer Pythons.
3. Release the branch as `secretstorage 3.0`. Make `setup.py` select `secretstorage<3` for older Pythons. I think I prefer this option, but I may consider others too.
4. Try to fork Jeepney and add Python 2 / 3.4 support?

What do you think?

items.title: Keyring errors should derive from a base class
items.body:
Quoting the python [guidance on user-defined exceptions](https://docs.python.org/3.6/tutorial/errors.html#tut-userexceptions):
> When creating a module that can raise several distinct errors, a common practice is to create a base class for exceptions defined by that module, and subclass that to create specific exception classes for different error conditions

This is useful for programs that call a module/package to identify the source of runtime errors.
 
The keyring errors `InitError` `PasswordSetError` and `PasswordDeleteError` should derive from a base class `KeyringError`

items.title: Reopening KWallets
items.body:
Hi,

unfortunately, here's yet another issue with kwallets.. 😢 

This time, it's triggered by the following steps:
 * open `kwallet` keyring
   * if not yet opened, it asks for the `kwallet` password
   * if `kwallet` was opened already, it asks for confirmation of this app to access the wallet (unless you permitted access to this app generally before)
 * fetch passwords from `kwallet`
 * force close the wallet (via `kwalletmanager`) 
 * when fetching more passwords now, one would expect another request for permission, but `get_password()` simply fails (returning None)

I found a workaround, but it's **butt ugly**. If `get_password()` fails, I reset the backend handle to -1, and reinitialize the keyring. That forces the connection to re-establish, and requests either for the wallets password, or permission as expected. Hence, the `kwallet backend` is missing some **disconnection detection** to handle this situation gracefully. `connected()` does not fit this purpose...

Any idea anybody, how to approach this properly?

In that environment, if one attempts to import dbus, one gets:

>>> import dbus

  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/keyring/backend.py", line 142, in _load_backends
    list(map(_load_backend, backends))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/keyring/backend.py", line 133, in _load_backend

    return _bootstrap._gcd_import(name[level:], package, level)

items.title: The documentation should be clear of whether password can be bytes or only unicode
items.body:
All the below applies to Python 3 only.
Some backends (i.e. SecretStorage) accept bytestrings as passwords, others (the file backend) do not.

But there is some code that tries to use bytestrings as passwords and [fails](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/python-keyring/+bug/1685547) with the file backend.

We should either fix the file backend (which is now in `keyrings.alt`) and make sure all other backends support bytes too, or fix the documentation to clearly say that the password should be a unicode string.

On Windows this code
```
def _load_backends():
    "ensure that native keyring backends are loaded"
    backends = 'kwallet', 'OS_X', 'SecretService', 'Windows'
    list(map(_load_backend, backends))
    _load_plugins()
```
Will load OS_X, which in turns imports _OX_X_API.py, which attempts to open 

`C:\system\library\frameworks\security.framework\versions\a\security.dll`
and
`C:\system\library\frameworks\coreservices.framework\versions\a\coreservices.dll`

That's a security vulnerability (binary planting) as a any local user on that machine can create the above paths, placing a nefarious dll in that location which will then run as the target user.
